title: A multi-scale methodology for explaining data streams

author: Luka Stopar, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: So my name is Lucas Topper.
I work here at Jsi and I'll present the work that we've been doing entitled, entitled, Multiscale methodology for explaining data streams.
So this is an outline of my presentation, so first I'll give an introduction with some motivating example.
Then I'll go into the implementation for first just the high level overview and then some some details.
Then I have one slide on the possible use cases and some ideas for further work.
Right, so the motivation would be that all sensory systems usually operate in cycles, right?
And they have a continuously time varying component.
Now an example of search on.
Of such systems would be an aircraft in flight, maybe some manufacturing systems, or just weather systems.
Right and we want to characterize such systems with the set of States and transitions.
So here I gave an example with an aircraft, so when it goes forward right, it's in state one, then it turns and it goes to state two and then it levels again and it's in state one again.
Right now, such such high level states could be further split into lower lower level states, right?
So for the example before, we could split the two states into free and then we would split them by the aircrafts roll right?
So here when it's going straight, it's still in state one, then when it turns a little bit it goes to State 2, then full turn is state Free State two again in state one.
Right so so then we get some hierarchy of states.
Right so so.
Huh?
Right, so so we we present a methodology for modeling such hierarchical systems here, and we call our implementation stream story.
Right, So what stream story does it consumes?
A set of input streams?
Then it automatically learns the States and the whole hierarchy and then finally.
Yeah, that's it.
OK, and it describes the underlying data structure in a quantitative way.
Oh, and by modeling the state transitions, it's able to predict future developments in the data.
So here here I gave an example from before, right?
So the aircraft here on the high level it's in state one and on the low level as well.
Then it starts turning and it goes to state two and low level on the high level.
It's still in state one full turn, its state two and state free then back to state two and one and one one.
But then what would happen if the pilot were to reduce the aircraft speed during the turn, right?
So we want to model such events.
So to do this, we split the incoming data streams into two sets.
So the first is the observation set.
This is the set that we assume that the pilot or the operator cannot directly manipulate.
Also, they they don't directly influence the dynamics of the system and we only use them to identify states.
So the other set is the control set, so this is the.
These are the attributes the attributes like injection pressure in a factory molding machine or whatever, or maybe maybe the throttle in an aircraft.
So these we assume, influence the dynamics, so we use them to model transitions.
And this allows our system to model the expected behavior right before actually changing the configuration.
Or so now I'll go into the implementation so.
This is kind of high level overview of what the system does, so we get multiple data streams on the input.
We first joined them to get feature vectors.
Then we re sample them so that their sample don't know once per second or whatever.
So we then cluster them to get states.
Then we aggregate them to get a hierarchy, and then finally we model the transitions.
So we implemented the system as a client server system with the core functionality implemented in C++ and then server side JavaScript acting as a glue between the functionality.
Right and then the user can build several models and apply them in real time or just use them to for exploration.
So this is the system architecture.
So here we have data streams that go into separate datastores.
Then we merge them then here we also resample them, then they go into a common store and then they are applied online by the models.
Or and then we have a separate Model store which is just for offline models.
The user can upload any data set there and just use it to explore.
And then all this communicates with the web interface and we have a database just to store user sessions and some data about the users.
So this is the architecture of a single model.
So basically the model has to what we call feature spaces which are used to generate feature vectors.
So so for example, this will just could be just to normalize the data.

And then then we have the stream modeler component which basically acts as glue for four subcomponents, and then then the model can communicate with the user either through Websockets if it wants to push a message or through traditional request response.
Yeah, so I will just talk about all of the components quickly.
So the stream model or this is the most important component here, and it basically adds excess glue between for other components.
That identifier hierarchy builder, transition model or in state assistance assistant.
Oh, and it just delegates tasks, right?
So then the.
The state identifier is used to.
Identify states of the system, right?
It does this by clustering.
It uses 2 algorithms for this.
One is K means and the other is dipping means, which is kind of similar.
It's just the the number of clusters isn't predefined.
Right and then then it starts some statistics about the States.
So here we can see it has the distribution of all the parameters.
On it computes the two 2D coordinates of the States so that we can visualize it.
Right and then in online mode we use it for the identification of the current state and for low level anomaly detection, which is clustering based.
Well then we have the hierarchy builder.
So this component, once we get this states it aggregates them into a hierarchy.
It stores the hierarchy in two arrays.
One is the topology array and the second one is.
The state level array.
This one basically 4 for each state, it just determines on what level it lives, right?
Or so we encode the hierarchy array like this.
So at the index I we store the index of Ice parent.
So that way once you start with states at the.
Bottom level, you can just go up when you see what's the current state or what's the.
Which aggregated state it belongs to.
And so next is the transition model, or so the transition model or user continuous time Markov chain framework to model transitions.
It determines the size of each state, which is proportional to the stationary distribution.
Then it models the average training time and transition probabilities.
Right and then?
If we want to get.
This model on a higher level right, we need to calculate which states are there and what the transitions are.
So on the input we get state sets here, so these are low level states which are aggregated and then we compute the transition intensities using this formula here.
Or so.
You remember I said before that we have this control set of parameters which are used to model state transitions, right?
So if you adjust one of these parameters, then the transition rates would change.
So we model this by by learning multiple logistic regression models.
So basically what we do?
So.
So here we are.
Let's say in state one and then.
We will construct several feature vectors for each of the possible next states.
And then if we in the next timestamp if we're still in one, we had a class label, one to state one and zero to every other state.
Then if we jump from one to two, we had a class label, one to state two, and zero for all the other states, right?
Then that's how we get transition probabilities and then we get intensities using this formula here.
Right and then how this looks in the UI.
You can select the state and then you can adjust this here and then.
This will get the probabilities will become different and then you get also different sizes of states.
Then it's the state assistant.
This one is used to.
Well, let the user identify what the state is about, right?
So what we do is you have.
The average value of a parameter in a state, and then it tells the user how.
Special this is for this state, right?
So if if the.
If the value is green or red, this means that this parameter value is special.
If it's great, then it's just average compared to other states, right?
And how we do this?
Well, we build logistic regression model classifying the feature vectors of 1 state against all the other States and then we extract the weights.
And the user interface looks like this.
Basically, once the user opens the interface, you get 2 states here with some transitions and then they can Scroll down and the states get expanded and they might look like this.
Right then they can click on a state or they get details.
Here they get the distribution of parameters.
Yeah, and then then if you use the model in real time.
Then this green state is the current state of the system.
Then the blue states are the possible next States and this is the best state.
So here are some details about the the user interface, so this is the visualization panel.
It's the most important panel.

So it displays states as circles and transitions as arrows, and then it has a few special states which I already mentioned before, so current state, previous state, future States and the Gray states are just normal states.
And then in each state it displays the ID and the average holding time at which is once you arrive in there, you're going to be there for.
I don't know .117 or one hour.
So then it has some other features, right?
So you can click on some target attribute.
Or let's say I don't know RPM and then the states with high RPM will become green.
The states with low RPM will become red.
Then we have the state details panel.
So here here we show some details about the state.
We showed the distribution of parameters in a state.
We let the user adjust the control parameters and see what happens with the model.
They can name a state so that it looks prettier.
So.
And they can.
They can make the state of target right?
So this is for monitoring.
So once it's a target, then every time the system will come to that state, they'll get a message.
And the use cases.
So what we could do with this?
It can be used for data exploration.
Then we can use it for anomaly detection.
Then root, cause analysis and prediction and it's being deployed on two case studies.
Andf

For further work well, we would like to improve the transition modeling 'cause currently we just model the transitions on the lowest level, but we could also include some higher level information and then implementing new features.
So.
Any questions?
Question.
Can this target state when you set it in the user interface can be also used for that you predict you have a certain threshold when you will.
Yeah, you can.
Also you can have this time horizon, let's say 2 hours and then it will give you the probability of arriving there in 2 hours.
OK.
Thank you.
